Title.evidence: Efficacy of Intraoperative NSAIDs on Postoperative Pulmonary Complications in NSCLC: A Retrospective Analysis

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Peking University Cancer Hospital, the study included NSCLC patients who underwent lung resection from January 1 to May 31, 2019.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were categorized into two groups: those receiving NSAIDs (NSAIDs group) and those not receiving NSAIDs (control group).

Objective.evidence: This retrospective study aimed to assess the impact of intraoperative non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) on postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) undergoing lung resection.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of PPCs within 7 days post-surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 306 patients analyzed, 139 were in the NSAIDs group and 167 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The NSAIDs group exhibited significantly lower frequencies of postoperative pneumonia (5.9% vs. 13.4%, P=0.048) and respiratory failure (0.8% vs. 5.9%, P=0.03) compared to the control group.
